item.title: Coronavirus: New guidance on face masks and coverings released for England
item.description: Customers in enclosed spaces such as shops, banks and post offices will have to wear a covering from Friday.

item.title: Dyson cuts 900 jobs amid coronavirus impact
item.description: The company behind the first bag-less vacuum cleaner said 600 of the cuts would be in the UK.

item.title: Brexit: Trade deal some way off, say UK and EU
item.description: UK and EU negotiators say a deal remains possible, but progress has not been made in difficult areas.

item.title: Amber Heard: I loved Depp, but he could be a monster
item.description: The US actress "always held out hope" her former husband would get clean, the High Court hears.

item.title: Coronavirus in Scotland: Relaxation of shielding to allow indoor visits
item.description: The first minister announces the relaxation of restrictions around those shielding from Covid-19

item.title: Mercury Prize 2020: Female artists lead nominations for the first time
item.description: Female artists and female-fronted bands outnumber men on the shortlist for the first time ever.

item.title: How long does it take to get to Mars - and why is it so difficult?
item.description: Summer 2020 is a popular time for missions to Mars because of the way the planets align - but how long does it take to get there?

item.title: Blackbaud Hack: Universities lose data to ransomware attack
item.description: At least six UK universities and one in Canada were affected by attack on a cloud computing provider.

item.title: Coronavirus: Boris Johnson says response shows 'might of UK union'
item.description: Boris Johnson visits Scotland as the SNP says he is worried about support for independence.

item.title: Taylor Swift announces surprise lockdown album Folklore
item.description: The singer's hitherto un-announced eighth album will arrive on Friday.

item.title: Coronavirus: Walk-in centres 'to help cope with winter'
item.description: Officials are worried people are still not coming forward for testing when they are infected.

item.title: Jason Lawrance appeal: Lying about fertility is not rape, say judges
item.description: Court of Appeal judges have quashed the convictions of a rapist who lied about having a vasectomy.

item.title: Coronavirus: People with learning disabilities 'at risk of falling through cracks'
item.description: A survey suggests that only 5% of disabled people feel safe to come out of lockdown.

item.title: In pictures: 10 years of One Direction
item.description: An anniversary look back at the boy band, from being talent show hopefuls to world pop sensations.

item.title: Taika Waititi on charity, homeschooling, racism and Star Wars
item.description: Thor and Jojo Rabbit filmmaker Taika Waititi tells BBC News what life has been like during lockdown

item.title: Germany's Ritter Sport wins square chocolate battle against Milka
item.description: Swiss chocolate-maker Milka challenged the German bar's right to be the only square bar in Germany.

item.title: QAnon, coronavirus and the conspiracy cult
item.description: The bizarre, fringe theory has surged in popularity in the US during the coronavirus pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: App to show beachgoers crowd levels
item.description: The phone app shows which beaches are crowded along 15 miles of coastline.

item.title: 'I just love helping, I'm not ready to give it up'
item.description: Dr Melissa Freeman is a doctor in New York City who has been practising for 65 years. The BBC spoke to her about her journey into medicine.

item.title: Guitar sales rise as UK gets into lockdown groove
item.description: As more people learn guitar amid lockdown, the UK's biggest online seller of instruments sees sales surge.

item.title: Birmingham students' pain to be the best at Bhangra
item.description: One dancer compares the bid to beat competition rivals with going to war.

item.title: Coronavirus: Will people be rushing back to the gym?
item.description: Indoor gyms reopen in England on Saturday - but with the rise of home workouts will people return?

item.title: Top 10 tips for diversifying your workplace
item.description: How can firms diversify workplaces? Race equality business champion Karen Blackett has some tips.

item.title: Is it legal to send federal forces into US states?
item.description: President Trump is sending federal agents to some US cities to tackle crime, despite local officials disputing his power to do that.

item.title: Anthony Walker: How a life lost in racist killing has been imagined for TV
item.description: A TV drama imagines the future life of Anthony Walker, who was killed in a racist attack in 2005.

item.title: Abood Hamam: 'A picture can kill you or save your life'
item.description: For years Abood Hamam sent war photos out of Syria anonymously. Now he's using his name, and urging exiles to return.

item.title: George Floyd death: The other names we're also hearing now
item.description: For some bereaved relatives fighting for justice the spotlight can be welcome, but it's still painful

item.title: Taking on the 'boys' club' of the music business
item.description: Radio 1 Newsbeat speaks to the people trying to open doors into the industry.

item.title: Russia report: What would tougher spy laws mean for UK?
item.description: A look at the likely challenges of introducing new laws to tackle the threat of Russian interference.

item.title: Archer back in England squad for final Test
item.description: Pace bowler Jofra Archer is included in the England squad for the deciding Test against West Indies.

item.title: Liverpool 5-3 Chelsea: Jurgen Klopp 'couldn't be more proud' after Reds lift trophy
item.description: Liverpool boss Jurgen Klopp says he couldn't be more proud after his side played an "exciting" final home game of their Premier League winning season beating Chelsea 5-3.

item.title: Top Premier League moments of the season - we've picked them, you rank them
item.description: From Liverpool's title win to Son Heung-win's wonder goal, BBC Sport looks back at 12 significant moments from this season's Premier League.

item.title: England v West Indies: Watch the best of Ben Stokes' second Test display
item.description: Watch highlights of Ben Stokes' impressive all-round performance, which helped England square the series against West Indies with victory in the second Test.

item.title: Britain's Greatest Olympic Moments: Nicola Adams wins boxing gold at London 2012
item.description: BBC Sport looks back at Nicola Adams' gold medal at London 2012 as she became the first women's boxing champion in Olympic history.

item.title: Coronavirus cure: What progress are we making on treatments?
item.description: Teams around the world are looking into medicines for Covid-19 and scientists are starting to discover what works.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules for face masks or face coverings?
item.description: England will follow Scotland by making face coverings compulsory in shops.

item.title: Coronavirus: What powers do the police have?
item.description: Coronavirus lockdown rules are changing across the UK, but who is responsible for enforcing them?

item.title: How to stop your glasses steaming up with a face mask on
item.description: Three simple tips to stop your glasses fogging up while you shop with a mask or face covering on.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does the 'eat out to help out' scheme work?
item.description: Diners will get money off their bill on certain days to help kickstart the hospitality industry.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the care home visiting rules in England?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to relatives wanting to visit care homes.

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: When will we have one?
item.description: About 200 groups of medical researchers around the world are working on a vaccine for Covid-19.

item.title: Coronavirus UK map: How many confirmed cases are there in your area?
item.description: Key graphics explaining how coronavirus has spread in the UK and the government's response.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where can I go on holiday? A guide to destinations
item.description: As people in the UK get the green light to go abroad again, here's a look at what's in store for travellers.

item.title: Coronavirus: How are indoor gyms and pools going to open?
item.description: As lockdown eases in England, more activities are being allowed but how are customers being kept safe?

item.title: Coronavirus vaccine: Might it have side-effects?
item.description: Questions about how a vaccine might work and other coronavirus topics.

item.title: Coronavirus: Young people on benefits double in lockdown
item.description: Experts fear it may take up to four years for youth unemployment to recover from the pandemic.

item.title: Coronavirus: What closes in a local lockdown?
item.description: Local authorities will be given the power to take action on coronavirus outbreaks in their area.

item.title: Does getting coronavirus make you immune?
item.description: What you need to know about how the immune system works.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the UK's travel rules and which countries can you visit?
item.description: New agreements mean people entering the UK from certain countries will not have to quarantine.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are social distancing and self-isolation rules?
item.description: Social distancing and lockdown rules are changing in England - but what can you now do?

item.title: Coronavirus: What's the risk on transport?
item.description: People are being asked to return to work, meaning public transport could become more crowded.

item.title: Coronavirus: Can my boss force me to go back to work?
item.description: The advice about going back to the workplace in England will change from 1 August.

item.title: Coronavirus: How does contact tracing work?
item.description: People who have been in close contact with someone found to have Covid-19 are now being traced.

item.title: Bowling alleys and casinos to reopen - what will they look like?
item.description: Bowling shoes could become a thing of the past says one firm, as it prepares to reopen in August.

item.title: Coronavirus: What are the rules on weddings?
item.description: Many weddings were cancelled during lockdown, while some will have to change to meet the new rules.

item.title: Coronavirus: How the financial shockwave is affecting jobs and money
item.description: With the UK facing a severe economic downturn, what is the outlook for our personal finances?

item.title: Unemployment rate: How many people are out of work?
item.description: The number of people claiming benefits has surged, but the unemployment rate has barely moved. Why?

item.title: Coronavirus: Did 'herd immunity' change the course of the outbreak?
item.description: What drove the government's thinking in the crucial stages of the coronavirus outbreak?
